src.data_structures package¶

Submodules¶

src.data_structures.half_edge module¶

Contains HalfEdge class, which is generally used in polygonal subdivision data structures like src.data_structures.polygonal_subdivision.BoundedPolygonalSubdivision.

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

class src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge(point: Optional[numpy.ndarray] = None, twin: Optional[src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge] = None, link: Optional[src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge] = None, prev: Optional[src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge] = None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A HalfEdge is the most basic building block of a polygonal subdivision. HalfEdges connect two points that are joined by an edge.

Since a single edge separates two faces, we split each edge in half so that we can associate a HalfEdge with a single face.

The HalfEdge stores the point from which they originiate.

HalfEdges are cyclically linked so that if we keep calling link or twin, we will get back to our starting HalfEdge after visiting all other HalfEdges in the same face.

Each HalfEdge’s other half is called it’s twin. Going from a HalfEdge to its twin will change the current face in the polygonal subidvision.

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

twin: src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge = None¶

Other HalfEdge defining the same edge as this HalfEdge

src.data_structures.point module¶

A point is a point in \(\mathbb{R}^d\), where \(d\) is the dimension of the space in which the point lives. Generally, we’ll work with points in \(\mathbb{R}^2\).

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

src.data_structures.point.point(*coords, z=1) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Creates a new point in any number of dimensions.

Parameters

  • coords (float) – Coordinates of point

  • z (float) – Final “z” coordinate of point. Defaults to 1 to make things like src.data_structures.utils.orient() easier, but can be 0 to simulate points infinitely far away in the direction of coords as a vector.

Returns

A numpy array of point like (coords, z).

Return type

numpy.ndarray

src.data_structures.polygon module¶

Contains the Polyogn class.

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

class src.data_structures.polygon.Polygon(points: list)[source]¶

Bases: object

A Polygon is a sequence of points in \(\mathbb{R}^2\). Edges are the convex closure of subsequent vertices. Each edge connects two vertices and each vertex is incident to two edges.

equal_up_to_translation(other: src.data_structures.polygon.Polygon) → bool[source]¶

A polygon \(A\) is equal to a polygon \(B\) up to translation iff there is some translation \(d\) such that \(A = B + d\).

Parameters

other (Polygon) – Polygon to compare against

Returns

True if this polygon and other are equal to to translation, where equal is defined by the src.data_structures.polygon.Polygon.__eq__() method.

Return type

bool

is_convex() → bool[source]¶

A simple polygon is convex iff any line with both endpoints in or on the polygon is completely contained in the polygon.

Returns

True if this polygon is convex, else False

Return type

bool

is_simple() → bool[source]¶

A polygon is simple if none of its edges cross each other.

Returns

True iff this polygon is simple, else False.

Return type

bool

src.data_structures.polygonal_subdivision module¶

Contains the BoundedPolygonalSubdivisonClass.

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

class src.data_structures.polygonal_subdivision.BoundedPolygonalSubdivision(bottom_left: numpy.ndarray, top_right: numpy.ndarray)[source]¶

Bases: object

A polygonal subdivision is a collection of linked src.data_structures.half_edge.HalfEdge. It extends the idea of a linked list into 2D, which adds geometry to the data structure, allowing it to represent a connected group of polygons partitioning the plane.

A BoundedPolygonalSubdivision is a little more restrictive than a general polygonal subdivision.

  1. As the name suggests, the polygonal subdivision is bounded within a box, meaning we don’t partition the entire plane like in a polygonal subdivision.

  2. The only way to add to the polygonal subdivision is to add a straight line through the bounding box. This restriction gurantees that all faces within the bounding area are convex.

add_line(line: tuple)[source]¶

Given a line create the line between them in the subdivision.

Parameters

line (tuple[ndarray]) – A tuple of two points on the outer boundary

Returns

A list of src.data_structures.polygon.Polygon that contain some portion of the zone_line.

Return type

list[Polygon]

Return type

Iterate over the vertices (points) connected by an edge to p in CCW order.

Parameters

Returns

An generator over the neighbor points of p

Return type

Raises

src.data_structures.utils module¶

This module contains several methods that don’t nicely fit into a single data structure. The might be used accross several data structures.

Authors

  • William Boyles (wmboyles)

src.data_structures.utils.lex_compare(p1: numpy.ndarray, p2: numpy.ndarray) → int[source]¶

Compare two points lexiographically. (0,0) < (0,1) < (1,0) < (1,1).

Parameters

  • p1 (ndarray) – First point to compare

  • p2 (ndarray) – Second point to compare

Returns

-1 if p1 < p2, 0 if p1 == p2, and 1 if p1 > p2 lexiographically

Return type

int

src.data_structures.utils.orient(*points: numpy.ndarray) → int[source]¶

Checks if the final point is above (-1), below (1), or coplaner with the previous \(n\) points.

Parameters

points (ndarray) – \(n+1\) points in \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\)

Returns

-1, 0, or 1 depending on orientation of points.

Return type

int

src.data_structures.utils.segment_intersection(a: numpy.ndarray, b: numpy.ndarray, c: numpy.ndarray, d: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Given four points a,b,c,d defining two line segments a–b and c–d, determine at what point they cross.

Parameters

  • a (ndarray) – One endpoint of segment a–b

  • b (ndarray) – Other endpoint of segment a–b

  • c (ndarray) – One endpoint of segment c–d

  • d (ndarray) – Other endpoint of segment c–d

Returns

The point at which segment a–b intersects c–d

Return type

ndarray or None

src.data_structures.utils.segments_cross(a: numpy.ndarray, b: numpy.ndarray, c: numpy.ndarray, d: numpy.ndarray) → bool[source]¶

Checks if segment a–b intersects segment c–d in a non-overlapping way. If all 4 points are colinear, that is considered overlapping. However, if the lines form a “T” shape, that is not overlapping.

Parameters

  • a (ndarray) – One endpoint of segment a–b

  • b (ndarray) – Other endpoint of segment a–b

  • c (ndarray) – One endpoint of segment c–d

  • d (ndarray) – Other endpoint of segment c–d

Returns

True iff the segments are not colinear and intersect, else False

Return type

bool
